learning_outcomes.description: Conceptualise and design novel ideas for journalism practice
Evaluate designed artefacts in the context of technological innovation

assessments.task_description:
Each student should identify a public interest issue or story and undertake contextual research focused on storytelling and technology.

Use this assignment to critique the design/s of journalism on your chosen topic. Aim to articulate the dominant forms of storytelling, the use of technology, and the nature of interactions. This will provide material for developing new ideas.

The Design Brief needs to:

  • Identify a public interest story or topic and explain your rationale for examining it
  • Describe current practices in terms of how the issue is generally told and designed
  • Demonstrate use of original, design-led research techniques to develop insights
  • Identify paths for investigating new forms of storytelling and engagement.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

Please consult the task sheet on Blackboard for more details, including structure and grading.

assessments.task_description:
Each student must prepare two portfolios that detail the response to a public interest issue or story, documents the design process and reflects on journalism.

Submission includes:

  • Design portfolio
  • Methods portfolio
  • Supplementary files [optional]

All artefacts, whether digital or physical, need to be retained for 30 days after the release of grades. Any files hosted on a third-party platform should be downloaded or exported.
